Award.AwardTitle: A Scholarship Program for Security Assured Information Systems Track

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to add three new cohorts to the existing SFS program at the University of Pittsburgh. The scholarship recipients are required to complete a master's degree in Information Science or Telecommunication and Networking with the Security Assured Information Systems (SAIS) track option. Ph.D. students in either program with an Information Assurance concentration are allowed to seek support for the last two years of their studies. The scholarship students benefit from a multidisciplinary educational environment and a strong IA curriculum, which is among the few in the nation that have been certified for all five national IA educational standards set by the Committee on National Systems Security (CNSS).

Scholarship students are provided with appropriate mentoring support throughout their stay at the university. The scholarship program places significant emphasis on the recruitment of underrepresented groups in IA areas through its links with minority serving postsecondary institutions such as the University of Puerto Rico, Mayaguez, which is a partner in the curriculum development effort, and Lincoln University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Goals: The major goals of the proposed work was to support through scholarship 12 students over the 5 year period (as initially proposed). These students would pursue the Information Security tracks of studies at the University of Pittsburgh's School of Computing and Information (SCI) -- SCI is a new school that started in July 2017; the PIs from SCI were faculty in the School of Information Sciences, which does not exist anymore and has been replaced by SCI. The information security curriculum at SCI was certified by the NSA since 2004 as meeting the 5 CNSS standards (to be expired in 2018). The curriculum was later certified under the new NSA Knowledge Units in 2014 (valid till 2021). 

As part of this project, the supported students were to be engaged in enriching research and/or educational activities, carry out internships and subsequently, upon graduation, to fulfill their obligations by serving in the federal/state/local government related units. The project also aimed to address the diversity issue in STEM education and emphasized research/development activities for the scholarship students.

Summary of Key Outcomes: The key outcomes of the project can be summarized as follows:

  • A total of 14 SFS students were supported by this project. Except for one student, all maintained a GPA > 3.50, indicating highly competent graduates out of this program. 
  • 50% of the total SFS students supported were female (i.e., 7 female students). And two of the female SFS supported were African-American.
  • Students were engaged in research and development, cybersecurity outreach and other program development activities. Students organized some workshops/tutorials for increasing cybersecurity awareness (e.g., at the school, in a high school, at a library, etc.). Two of the SFS students opted for MS Thesis research option. Several SFS students also published research work in conferences (as regular papers or posters). Samples of publications by SFS students (SFS students indicated in bold) are as follows:

Balaji Palanisamy Sheldon Sensenig, James Joshi Rose Constantino (2014). LEAF: A Privacy?conscious Social Network? based Intervention Tool for IPV Survivors.  IEEE IRI.  


Jonathan Spring, Sarah Kern, Alec Summers (2015). Global Adversarial Capability Modeling. 2015 APWG Symposium on Electronic Crime Research.  eCrime 2015. Barcelona, Spain.  


Shauna Policicchio and Attila A. Yavuz (2015). Preventing Memory Access Pattern Leakage in Searchable Encryption.  iConference.  
 

Shauna Policicchio. Bulk Analysis of Malicious PDF Documents  (2015).  University of Pittsburgh. (MS THESIS)
 

Angela Horneman. Examining Threat Groups from the Outside: Generating High?Level Overviews of Persistent and Traditional Compromises. (2013).  University of Pittsburgh. (MS THESIS)

Intellectual Merit & Broader Impacts: The project contributed towards addressing the increasing national demand for high caliber Cybersecurity workforce, by graduating 14 high caliber Information Security graduates who finished an Information Security track of study certified for five CNSS certifications (CNSS 5011 - 5015) as well the newly created NSA Knowledge Unit requirements. Various research and development, outreach and program enrichment activities have provided broader experiential learning to these SFS graduates.

The project supported a total of 50% female students ? addressing the low enrollment of female students in STEM education in general and in IS/CS or Cybersecurity areas in particular. Participation of women in Cybersecurity areas has specially been very low and addressing it has been a national priority as well as that of the NSF SFS program. Two of the female SFS students were African-American. The SFS activities also helped enrich the LERSAIS lab. LERSAIS has been a NSA/DHS designated Center of Academic Excellence in Cyber Defense (both CAE and CAE-Research) for over a decade.
